entry.title: Best practices for keeping up with the SAP Activate content updates
entry.content:
In this post, I intend to share practices and resources that will help you stay in step with the rapid and regular updates in the SAP Activate road maps that SAP delivers to our customers both on the SAP Activate road map viewer (link) and in the SAP Cloud ALM application. We deliver these updates to keep the implementation guidance in step with the innovations introduced in the product and to give our users the latest, up-to-date guidance and accelerators that help them run their transformation projects better. Most of our road maps are on a bi-weekly update cycle, and in some updates, we deliver minor refinements of the content that users may not even notice, while in other updates, we introduce significant updates to support our users in adopting new capabilities.

For example earlier in this year when SAP released Parallel Line capability to all our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public customers on 3-system landscape, the SAP Activate guidance delivered several new tasks and accelerators to help our users to learn about this new capability, request provisioning of the parallel line tenants and explanation on how to use this functionality for parallel configuration activities and how to use transports in this parallel line. There are also examples for the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, where some of our latest additions were bringing the guidance for use of WalkMe, refinement of the Clean Core Quality Gates, and new content for RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. To name just a few.

Now, how can we best keep up with these ongoing updates? There are two main sources for information, one in each of our tools, where SAP delivers SAP Activate to our users. Let’s start with the SAP Activate in the road map viewer.

Release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer

For the most frequently updated SAP Activate road maps, like SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, you can find dedicated release notes on the Overview page of the road map in the application. See the screenshot below with the highlighted section where you can access the release notes.

When you open the link, you will download a document with release notes that are updated every time we release a new update. These notes provide an overview of the key updates delivered with the new content release. This document is a great source for staying up to date with the new content delivered in each update. You can review it on a regular basis to stay up to date on all the key updates delivered in the SAP Activate road map.

Detailed content update summary in SAP Cloud ALM

Users of SAP Cloud ALM may have noticed a tile “SAP Content Update Summary” in the Project Overview app (see the screenshot below). The tile provides detailed information about how many tasks have been updated (blue bubble), how many new tasks were delivered in the content update (light gray bubble), and how many tasks have been deprecated (dark gray bubble).

The user can click on each bubble to go to the detailed task list for each category (see the screenshot below). In this screen, you can open the task details by selecting it, assess whether it is relevant to your project, and accordingly assign it to the user or team. If it is not relevant, mark it as such with the status “Not Relevant.”

Now, let’s look at the “Updated” tasks. We will access the task list the same way we did in the previous step from the Project Overview screen. Then, in the list, we can pick one task to review the details of the change. You will access the “History” details by selecting the “…” at the top right side of the screen and selecting the “History” item from the menu (see below).

The history opens to the right of the task. In this section of the screen, you can select the time frame for the history (filter button on the right) or change the sorting how the history is shown (sort button on the left). The sorting will present the history from the latest changes at the top (default) or you can change it to see the oldest changes at the top.

This way, you can see all the detailed changes of the content that have been delivered to your project. Like in the example for new tasks, you can assess if the updated task is relevant for your project and if the assigned owner can carry it out. Use the Status and Comments on the task to keep track of your actions and communication with the task owner.

Note that this capability works for both projects created with single SAP Activate roadmap as well as the projects utilizing combined roadmaps in SAP Cloud ALM. In our example, we used a combined roadmap with content from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3-system landscape, SAP SuccessFactors, the Adoption Plan for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Concur.

I hope that this blog post helped you understand how to best utilize the release notes and detailed content history in SAP Cloud ALM to keep yourself up to date on the release updates and your project task list. Please share your feedback in the comments and let me know if you already use these features and what your experience is.

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is “clean core”?

Let’s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: An SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called “clean core extensibility”. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, as the Public Cloud Edition cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the public cloud, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model – Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP S/4HANA, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core—decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability—remain essential.

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP S/4HANA system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP S/4HANA, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP S/4HANA

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes – all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP’s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP S/4HANA.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP’s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP S/4HANA and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you’re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: Managing Legacy Files for India GSTR reports in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance
entry.content:
Introduction 

When implementing SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for GST reporting in India, it may be necessary to store legacy GST-filed documents and responses (for example, GSTR1 filling json, GSTR3B etc.) from the GSTN for future reference and audit purposes. This blog presents a practical approach to manually storing and managing previously reported files within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance by using Attachment section in the Generated Run. 

Disclaimer: This document does not replace a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Part 1: Technical Prerequisites 

Step 1: Create a Custom Report Definition 

Begin by setting up a custom report definition to manage historical files. This involves: 

  • Custom Report Definition: Tailor a report specifically for historical data. 
  • Corresponding Report Category: Categorize the report appropriately. 
  • Custom Entity: Create if necessary. 

 for example, ZIN_GSTR1 or YIN_GSTR1 etc. 

Note: Either you can use the same Z or Y report created above, across multiple GST reports or you can create a new report based on the functionality. 

Refer to SAP Documentation for detailed instructions on defining statutory reports SAP Documentation – Define Statutory Reports for creating above-mentioned objects. 

Step 2: Define a Schema 

During setting up the document section in report definition, you must specify a schema or ABAP structure to define the document layout. Use the following sample JSON structure to facilitate file uploads: 

{ 

    "title": "India GSTR Reporting", 

    "type": "object", 

    "properties": { 

        "CompanyCode": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[0-9]{4}$", 

            "description": "4-digit company code" 

        }, 

        "Country": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[a-zA-Z]{2}$", 

            "description": "2-letter ISO country code (e.g., IN or In)" 

        } 

    } 

}

Save this schema as a .json file and upload it during report definition configuration. 

Note: The same schema can be used across multiple GST reports. 

Step 3: Configure Document Mapping 

Assign static (literal) values for required fields to simplify the upload process, such as: 

  • Company Code: 1810 
  • Country: IN 

 

 

  

Part 2: Storing Attachments in Document and Reporting Compliance 

Step 1: Generate a Report Run 

Create a new reporting run for the relevant period. This serves as a placeholder for document storage. 

Note: This run is intended only to facilitate document storage. Make sure to consider any storage limitations related to the attachment service. 

Disclaimer: It is not a substitute for a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Step 2: Navigate to the Run 

Locate your custom report and the run you created in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance application. 

 

 

Step 3: Access the Attachments Tab 

Switch to the Attachments tab within the selected run. 

 

 

Step 4: Upload Your Historical File 

Click on Upload and select the desired historical file from your computer

 

 

Step 5: Save the Attachment 

Click Save Attachment to securely store the file in the system for future reference. 

 

 

Conclusion 

By utilizing custom report definitions and the Attachments feature, organizations can centralize access to both new and historical statutory filing records within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. This method ensures a consistent and auditable compliance process, regardless of your adoption timeline or transitions between reporting solutions.

entry.title: ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
End of 2022 we launched ABAP Cloud and published the new ABAP extensibility guide. This guide is the best starting point for overview of ABAP Cloud development model and ABAP-based extensibility options for SAP S/4HANA in the cloud and on-premise. The last update of the extensibility guide took place in May 2023 where we incorporated the feedback of early adaptors of ABAP Cloud in real SAP S/4HANA systems.

A key concept for extensibility in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and on-premise outlined in the ABAP extensibility guide was the 3-tier extensibility model. This model described how ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP can co-exist within a single system: tier 1 contained ABAP Cloud on-stack extensions, as well as any developments with SAP Build on SAP BTP for side-by-side extensions. Tier 2 served to address gaps, providing mechanisms to mitigate necessary publicly released SAP APIs not yet available in tier 1. Finally, tier 3 encompassed classic ABAP extensions. Only tier 1 (and tier 2, when using recommended SAP objects) was considered as clean core. In contrast, tier 3 was classified as “not clean.” The ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness controlled the usage of classic ABAP in custom extensions.

The main objective of the clean core dimension Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA on-premise deployments is decoupling of custom extensions from SAP standard via use of ABAP Cloud and reliable development and extension technologies to reach upgrade stability. On the way to clean core, dealing with the classic ABAP custom code represents a challenge for SAP customers and partners. Multiple customer and partner interactions showed that the binary classification of custom code in the 3-tier extensibility model in “clean core” and “not clean core” and governance based on ABAP test cockpit checks for ABAP Cloud readiness were too restrictive and not applicable for systems with a lot of existing custom code developed with classic ABAP. Besides this there are also new custom extensions which need to be implemented with classic ABAP because for example the related SAP application area is not sufficiently covered by publicly released SAP APIs or is implemented with SAP GUI based technologies and frameworks. On the other hand, many of underlying SAP classic ABAP technologies, like ABAP List Viewer for example, incorporate an implementation stability which most likely will bring minimum upgrade risks and can be still utilized in classic ABAP developments.

The new Clean core extensibility white paper introduced by SAP incorporates evolution of the current 3-tier extensibility model with binary decisions on clean core to more detailed assessment of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept, allowing you as SAP customers and partners stepwise transformation to clean core at your own pace.

In a nutshell:

  • Level A are the cleanest custom extensions built either on-stack with ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side using any option of SAP Build on SAP BTP – ABAP Cloud, CAP or low-code/no-code tools

           Levels B-D relate to all classic ABAP developments and can be reached as follows:

  • Level B can be achieved by custom extensions that comply with SAP recommendations for the use of classic ABAP development technologies and the frameworks offered as classic SAP APIs
  • Level C contains custom extensions which cannot be qualified for Level B because of usage of arbitrary SAP internal objects. Under the condition that dedicated checks are performed before the release upgrade (following the changelog for SAP objects approach), these custom extensions can be considered conditionally clean.
  • Level D is not clean core and includes custom extensions with severe violations of SAP development recommendations like modifications, usage of not recommended SAP objects or extension technologies (e.g. implicit enhancements).

Following the new clean core extensibility guidance we have updated the ABAP extensibility guide with technical guidelines which are in line and support the clean core level concept for the classification of custom extensions.

Summary of technical ABAP extensibility guidelines for clean core


How the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) supports clean core level concept

Main updates for transformation of 3-tier extensibility model to clean core extensibility based on clean core level concept (see the activity log on page 1 of the ABAP extensibility guide for details):

  • Change technical guidelines for extensibility from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development and classic ABAP development
  • Explain classic SAP APIs and their matching to clean core levels
  • Provide ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of classic ABAP development for clean core
  • Explain relation of custom code use cases to clean core levels
  • Describe changelog for SAP objects approach for assessment of upgrade stability of custom code using SAP internal objects
  • Change transformation options for existing custom code from 3-tier extensibility model to ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP developments

Supporting the clean core extensibility and clean core level concept with these technical guidelines for ABAP extensibility is a next significant step forward to support your clean core transformation at your own speed.

If you have already set up the 3-tier extensibility model and are following clean core development practices, you might be wondering if the new guidance changes everything. Good news — you are already on the right track! The new clean core level concept simply provides enhanced guidance for everything you developed in tier 3 with classic ABAP.

If you now want to learn more about the refined clean core extensibility guidance and clean core levels, read the Clean core extensibility whitepaper.

For more information about ABAP Cloud and recommendations for classic ABAP developments, classic APIs, ABAP test cockpit setup and behavior for governance of clean core development supporting the clean core levels switch directly to the updated ABAP extensibility guide.

In addition, you can also use the updated ABAP Cloud - Extensibility slide deck . To get your questions answered use the ABAP Cloud FAQ and the ABAP Development community.

We will continue our ABAP Cloud and clean core collaboration with customers and partners and will share the new learnings and provide new updates. After this update related to the adaption of the new clean core extensibility model the next major update of the ABAP extensibility guide planned for Q4/2025 will focus on enhancements in ABAP custom code management tools and ABAP AI capabilities. Stay tuned!

entry.title: Advance Your Career as a Certified SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Project Manager
entry.content:
Around 60% of cloud buyers told IDC’s Cloud Pulse Survey in October 2024 that their business’ IT or digital infrastructure currently requires major transformation, and 82% said their cloud also requires modernization. In response to these pressing industry needs, effective project management has become essential, particularly for navigating complex cloud-based initiatives. The new certification for SAP Certified Associate - Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects (C_S4PM2) provides a unique opportunity for professionals to become certified project managers, equipping them to lead transformative digital efforts with expertise and strategic insight. 

Designed for Project Managers, Consultants, and Technical Leads, this certification empowers you to excel in managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations, positioning you to become a strategic leader in your organization's digital strategy, providing direction and specialist knowledge in project execution. 

How to prepare for this certification 

You can prepare for the exam in your own pace, by completing the "Managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Projects" learning journey, designed to provide comprehensive insight into SAP S/4HANA Cloud project management. With free access to the learning journey, you can deepen your expertise of managing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition projects, spotlighting SAP tools and strategic implementation methodologies. Among these, the RISE with SAP Methodology stands out as a vital, holistic approach tailored for cloud transformation journeys. 

Additionally, SAP Community blog posts provide some supporting information to deepen your understanding and preparation: 

  • 12 Things that SAP implementation methodology SAP Activate tells you to do 
  • Planning your System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition following SAP Activate 
  • SAP Activate for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition now available by Deployment Journey 
  • Conversion Guide for SAP S/4HANA 2023 for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023
  • Review the SAP Activate Minute videos in this playlist. 

You can also explore more insights about SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition on SAP for Me, and take a look at the release notes.  

As a prerequisite, candidates should possess project management experience, preferably in ERP implementation, especially SAP Cloud-related projects. Additionally, hands-on experience with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition solutions, knowledge of SAP Cloud ALM, and experience managing cloud-based SAP projects are beneficial.

Get started today 

Achieving the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition certification allows you to become a crucial asset in driving your organization's growth and innovation. This certification validates your 

competency in integrating business goals with technical solutions, enhancing your leadership role in cloud project management.  

Certified learners must regularly update their skills and keep certifications valid by completing mandatory annual assessments before expiration. With an SAP Learning Hub subscription, you can take these assessments anytime during your certification's validity.  

Build the skills you need on the SAP Learning site and get inspired by reading learner stories on SAP Community, ask questions and connect with fellow learners. When you’re ready, take your certification exam and start shaping your industry's future!

entry.title: 📦 Stock Transfer Posting in SAP GTM — A Hidden Gem in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
Why This Blog?

If you work with SAP Global Trade Management (GTM) and haven’t explored Stock Transfer Posting (STP) via the Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), you’re not alone.

This feature has been available since SAP S/4HANA 1809, yet many users may still be unaware of its potential — especially when it comes to handling internal stock movements such as plant-to-plant or storage location transfers within GTM.

This blog highlights this functionality, along with examples and key logic to help you understand when and how to use it.

 

Background

SAP Global Trade Management (GTM) was originally developed to support companies engaged in the trading of physical goods — particularly those operating as trading houses or wholesale distributors. Its core purpose is to provide an integrated framework for managing the complete trading lifecycle, covering both sales and purchase contracts in a unified way.

In earlier years, many trading companies primarily operated on drop shipment models, where goods moved directly from supplier to customer. As a result, there was limited business need for internal stock transfers, and such scenarios weren’t a key focus area.

Over time, however, business models evolved — with many global traders now operating their own plants and warehouses to manage imports, consolidation, or compliance requirements. This shift created the need for system-supported internal movements — still within the context of trading contracts and the Trading Execution Workbench (TEW).

SAP addressed this business requirement by enhancing Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) to support Stock Transfer Posting (STP).

 

What’s Supported?

With Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), the following stock transfer scenarios are supported:

🏭Scenario 1: Transfer Between Plants

When needed:
Material is received in one plant (e.g., an import hub) but later moved to another for processing or dispatch.

Example:
A global trader receives 2,000 KG of sugar at Plant 0001 (Port Warehouse).
Later, 100 KG is moved to Plant 0002 (Packing Unit) to fulfil customer deliveries.

 

📦Scenario 2: Transfer Between Storage Locations

When needed:
Material is received in a general storage location (e.g., dock or receiving), but needs to be moved to another location such as quality check, staging, or picking area.

Example:
1,000 KG of chemical drums arrive at Storage Location 0001 (Receiving).
100 KG is moved to Storage Location 0002 (Quality Check) for inspection.

 

🔁Scenario 3: Batch-to-Batch Transfer

When needed:
Material is received under a system-generated batch, but the sales contract or customer expects it under a different batch (e.g., regulatory or customer-approved).

Example:
100 KG of pharmaceutical raw material is received under Batch 1.
To fulfil the sales order, it must be reassigned to Batch 2 (as expected by the customer).
This is handled through a batch transfer using TEW.

 

🧱 Scenario 4: WBS Element Transfer (Project Stock)

When needed:
Project stock needs to be reassigned between WBS elements — such as different project phases or cost objects.

Example:
500 KG steel beams are procured under WBS Element A.
Due to project rescheduling, 100 KG of them are reassigned to WBS Element B for another phase.

 

⛔Scenario 5: Cancellation of Stock Transfer Posting

When needed:
A previously executed stock transfer needs to be reversed — due to an incorrect destination, wrong quantity, or a change in downstream planning.

Example:
A stock transfer of 600 KG from Plant A to Plant B is executed but later cancelled because planning changed.
The quantity is reversed, and position updates are rolled back accordingly.

These scenarios are supported via Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) and follow GTM’s association logic, ensuring consistency and traceability across the process.

 

How the System Decides What to Transfer

Before a stock transfer is posted, the system checks how much material is available — referred to as the open quantity.

Key Definitions:

  • Open Quantity: The quantity available for transfer, calculated differently for plant vs. non-plant transfers.
  • Associated Quantity: Quantity already associated between a sales and purchasing document.
  • Un-associated Quantity: Quantity that is not yet associated.

🔒SAP ensures that associated quantities must be moved in full — they cannot be split.

 

🔄Transfer Rules (Simplified)

1️. Plant Transfers

System allows movement of:

  • ✔️Unassociated quantity, or
  • ✔️Associated quantity (only if no sales order exists for the associated sales contract), or
  • ✔️A combination of both

2️. Storage Location / Batch / WBS Element Transfers

System allows movement of:

  • ✔️Un-associated quantity, or
  • ✔️Associated quantity or
  • ✔️A combination of both

 

Why This Matters

Using Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) for internal stock transfers enables GTM users to:

  • Keep all stock movements integrated with trading contracts and positions
  • Avoid manual workarounds or steps outside GTM
  • Ensure accurate position and association management

 

Summary

Stock Transfer Posting via Trading Execution Workbench (TEW), brings valuable capabilities to GTM by enabling seamless internal stock movements across plants, storage locations, batches, and project stock.

While this functionality has been available for a while, it remains a highly relevant feature — especially for businesses that manage their own logistics networks alongside trading operations.

If your GTM processes involve internal material movements, this is a powerful tool to help keep everything contractually aligned, auditable, and efficient.

 

Over to You

Have you already been using Trading Execution Workbench (TEW) for stock transfers in GTM, or is this something you're just now exploring?

Whether you're applying it for plant transfers, batch reclassification, or WBS stock movements — we'd love to hear how it's helping your process.

💬Share your experiences, tips, or questions in the comments — and let’s continue to grow awareness of this powerful and flexible GTM capability!

entry.title: Informacion y Configuracion de Business Partner en SAP CLOUR ERP Private Cloud [ARG - SFD #1]
entry.content:
¡Hola! Bienvenido a mi Post, espero que te encuentres muy bien.

Mi nombre es Matias, soy Consultor SAP, mi objetivo es brindarte contenido en Español directamente desde Argentina, Latinoamerica.

Hoy quiero mostrarte los fundamentos basicos de Business Partner y su configuracion dentro del sistema. Cualquier duda o consulta, no dudes en dejarmela en la seccion de comentarios.

Tambien, si esto te sirvió o te interesó por favor no dudes en hacer click en  asi le llega a mas personas.

Esta entrada se va a dividir en 3 secciones:

  1. Informacion Básica de Business Partner.
  2. Configuracion Básica de Business Partner (Greenfield).
  3. Temas relevantes para investigar.

1. Informacion Básica de Business Partner

¿Qué es un Business Partner?

SAP Business Partners (BP) en SAP S4HANA son entidades que representan a personas naturales, empresas, organizaciones y otros tipos de entidades comerciales con las que una empresa puede realizar acciones comerciales. Estas acciones pueden incluir ventas, compras, servicios, entre otras.

En el contexto de SAP S4HANA, la funcionalidad de SAP Business Partners ha evolucionado significativamente. Anteriormente, en versiones de SAP ECC, los clientes, proveedores y otros socios comerciales se mantenían en tablas separadas. En SAP S4HANA, todas estas entidades comerciales se almacenan en la tabla de SAP Business Partners. Además, SAP S4HANA también proporciona una gestión más amplia y completa de los datos maestros de los socios comerciales, lo que permite una mejor automatización de los procesos empresariales.

Categorias

Los datos disponibles para sus transacciones comerciales también dependen de la categoría del socio comercial.

La categoría de socio comercial indica si un socio comercial es una persona física (particular privado), una organización (persona/entidad jurídica o parte de una entidad jurídica, como un departamento) o un grupo.

Cuando se crea un socio comercial, se debe seleccionar una categoría de socio comercial. Dependiendo de la categoría del socio comercial, se debe completar un determinado conjunto de campos con datos.

La selección de campos de nombre disponibles está definida por la categoría de socio comercial. Puedes introducir los siguientes datos:

  • Persona: Dirección, nombre y apellido, otros componentes del nombre (como prefijos y afijos de nombre y título académico), género.
  • Organización: Domicilio, nombre, forma jurídica, industria, entidad jurídica.
  • Grupos: Domicilio, dos nombres, tipo de grupo de pareja (matrimonio, acuerdo de vivienda compartida)

Las categorías estándar de socios comerciales son:

  • Persona física (particular, humana)
  • Organización (por ejemplo: empresa, departamento de una empresa, club, asociación)
  • Grupo (por ejemplo: pareja casada, acuerdo de vivienda compartida)

No es posible crear otras categorías de socios comerciales. No se puede modificar la categoría de socio comercial en una etapa posterior.

Roles/Funciones de Business Partner

Un socio comercial puede asumir diferentes roles de socio comercial, lo que permite diferentes vistas de los datos del socio comercial según la función comercial. El rol determina que Derechos y obligaciones que puede asumir un socio comercial en diferentes transacciones comerciales. Se puede utilizar el rol de socio comercial para realizar una clasificación comercial de un socio comercial.

La base para la definición del rol de socio comercial es una transacción comercial. Los atributos del rol del BP dependen de la transacción particular involucrada. Los datos disponibles para una transacción también dependen de la categoría del socio comercial. Se puede crear un socio comercial en uno o más roles de BP. Los datos centrales como el nombre, la dirección y los datos bancarios solo deben crearse una vez (¡la magia de BP!).

Los roles que se suelen usar de manera general son:

  • 000000 - Interlocutor comercial central: Datos generales para todas las funciones
  • FLCU00 - Deudor (Finanzas - FI): Datos relevantes para contabilidad financiera en Cuentas a Cobrar (AR). Datos a nivel Sociedad FI.
  • FLCU01 - Cliente (Ventas - SD): Datos relevantes para ventas. Datos a nivel Organizacion de Ventas.
  • FLVN00 - Acreedor (Finanzas - FI): Datos relevantes para contabilidad financiera en Cuentas a Pagar (AP). Datos a nivel Sociedad FI.
  • FLVN01 - Proveedor (Compras - MM): Datos relevantes para compras. Datos a nivel Organizacion de Compras.
  • UMK00 - Gestión de Crédito (FSCM-CR): Datos relevantes para Gestión de Crédito.

 

2. Configuracion Básica de Business Partner (Enfoque Greenfield)

Clases de Interlocutor Comercial (Business Partner)

Las agrupaciones (o clases) de interlocutor comercial, son los grupos en los cuales daremos de alta nuestros Business partner. Mediante las agrupaciones podemos controlar la numeración del interlocutor comercial creado.
Hay dos tipos de numeraciones:

  • Interna: la asigna SAP automáticamente al momento de la creación.
  • Externa: la asigna un sistema externo o nosotros de manera manual.
Configurar Clases de Interlocutor Comercial (Business Partner)

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiplicaciones-> Interlocutor comercial central -> Interlocutor comercial -> Parametrizaciones básicas -> Clases de interlocutor comercial -> Definir clases de interlocutor comercial

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Hacemos click en :

En Clase de interlocutor: acrónimo de 4 caracteres alfanumérico para identificar al IC.

En denominación: descripción del acrónimo para identificar al IC.

Por último y lo incluimos en nuestra Orden de Transporte (OT).

Grupo de cuentas de Deudor

El grupo de cuentas es una recopilación de características que controlan la creación de registros maestros. Este determina qué campos deben, o pueden, rellenarse al crear el registro maestro. Se asignará un rango de números al grupo de la cuenta. Mediante éste se especifica la clase de la asignación de números y un intervalo de números. Las cuentas, que requieren los mismos campos de registro maestro y que utilizan el mismo rango de números, se crearán con el mismo grupo de cuentas.

Configuracion de Cuentas de Deudor

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de deudor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de deudores -> Definir grupo de cuentas con formato de pantalla (deudores)

Creamos el nuevo grupo y dentro lo configuramos:

Grupo de cuentas: acrónimo de 4 dígitos alfanumérico que identifica al grupo de cuentas de deudor

Significado: descripción del grupo de cuentas de deudor

Cuenta pro diversos: indica si el grupo de cuentas de deudor es CpD (Esporádico)

Omitir verificación de dirección: Con esta función puede omitir las verificaciones de campos de dirección como País e Idioma mientras crea una cuenta ocasional. Dependencias: Debe seleccionar la casilla de selección “Cuenta pro diversos” para habilitar la casilla de selección Omitir verificación de dirección.

Esquema para mensajes: Agrupación de mensajes permitidas dentro de una determinada operación comercial (pedido) (por ejemplo, mensajes de pedido).

En status campo, a nivel general, sociedad y ventas podremos determinar que campos son:

  • Suprimidos
  • Mandatorios
  • Opcionales
  • Solo Visualizar

Grupo de cuentas de Acreedor

El grupo de cuentas es una recopilación de características que controlan la creación de registros maestros. Este determina qué campos deben, o pueden, rellenarse al crear el registro maestro. Se asignará un rango de números al grupo de la cuenta. Mediante éste se especifica la clase de la asignación de números y un intervalo de números. Las cuentas, que requieren los mismos campos de registro maestro y que utilizan el mismo rango de números, se crearán con el mismo grupo de cuentas.

Configuracion de Cuentas de Acreedor

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de acreedor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de acreedores -> Definir grupo de cuentas con formato de pantalla (acreed.)

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Creamos el nuevo grupo y dentro lo configuramos:

Grupo de cuentas: acrónimo de 4 dígitos alfanumérico que identifica al grupo de cuentas de acreedor

Significado: descripción del grupo de cuentas de acreedor

Cuenta pro diversos: indica si el grupo de cuentas de acreedor es CpD (Esporádico)

Omitir verificación de dirección: Con esta función puede omitir las verificaciones de campos de dirección como País e Idioma mientras crea una cuenta ocasional. Dependencias: Debe seleccionar la casilla de selección “Cuenta pro diversos” para habilitar la casilla de selección Omitir verificación de dirección.

Esquema para mensajes: Agrupación de mensajes permitidas dentro de una determinada operación comercial (pedido) (por ejemplo, mensajes de pedido).

En status campo, a nivel general, sociedad y ventas podremos determinar que campos son:

  • Suprimidos
  • Mandatorios
  • Opcionales
  • Solo Visualizar

Numeracion de Business Partner

Son los rangos de numeración que se utilizaran para dar de alta Business Partners en SAP S/4HANA.

Configuracion de la Numeración para Clases/Agrupaciones de Business Partner (Cut - Over: BUCF)

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Interlocutor comercial central -> Interlocutor comercial -> Parametrizaciones básicas -> Rangos de números y agrupaciones -> Definir rangos de números

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Seleccionamos :

N° Rango de números: Acrónimo de 2 dígitos alfanumérico para identificar un rango de numero de BP dentro de SAP.

De Numero: límite inferior de un intervalo.

A Numero: límite superior de un intervalo.

Cont. Rango números: En este campo se indica el último número asignado en el intervalo de rango de números de asignación interna. (empeza desde TAL numero)

Ext.: Mediante este indicador se fija si el intervalo de rango de números será de asignación interna o de asignación externa. En intervalos de rango de números de asignación interna se asignarán los números automáticamente por el Sistema SAP. El número asignado automáticamente está entre el 'número de ' y el 'número a'. El último número asignado es grabado en el log como 'número actual'. En la asignación externa deberá indicar el usuario un número que deberá estár entre el 'número de' y el 'número a'.

Asignar Numeración de Business Partner (Agrupaciones o Clases)

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Interlocutor comercial central -> Interlocutor comercial -> Parametrizaciones básicas -> Rangos de números y agrupaciones -> Definir agrupaciones y asignar rangos de números

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Agrupacion: Clase/Agrupacion del Business Partner.

Denom. Breve.: Denominacion acotada de la clase/agrupación del Business Partner.

Denominacion: Denominacion extendida de la clase/agrupación del Business Partner.

Rango de números: Rango de numero asignado a la clase/agrupación del Business Partner.

Externo: Mediante este indicador se fija si el intervalo de rango de números será de asignación interna o de asignación externa. En intervalos de rango de números de asignación interna se asignarán los números automáticamente por el Sistema SAP. El número asignado automáticamente está entre el 'número de ' y el 'número a'. El último número asignado es grabado en el log como 'número actual'. En la asignación externa deberá indicar el usuario un número que deberá estár entre el 'número de' y el 'número a'.

Agrup. Estandar: Significa que esta agrupación interna se utiliza como agrupación estándar cuando se crea el Business Partner. El BDT selecciona esta agrupación estándar si, durante la creación, un interlocutor comercial no ha recibido la asignación de un número IC ni una agrupación.

Estandar ext.: Provoca que esta agrupación externa se utilice como agrupación estándar. El BDT selecciona esta agrupación estándar, si a un interlocutor comercial se le asigna un número de interlocutor comercial durante la creación, pero ninguna agrupación.

Suprimir: Controla si se ofrece una agrupación en la ayuda para entradas o en una lista desplegable.

Configuracion para grupos de Cuentas de Acreedor (Cut - Over: XKN1)

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de acreedor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de acreedores -> Crear rangos números para cuentas acreedor

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Seleccionamos:

N° Rango de números: Acrónimo de 2 dígitos alfanumérico para identificar un rango de numero de Acreedor dentro de SAP.

De Numero: límite inferior de un intervalo.

A Numero: límite superior de un intervalo.

Cont. Rango números: En este campo se indica el último número asignado en el intervalo de rango de números de asignación interna. (empeza desde TAL numero)

Ext. (En este caso es externo, porque la numeracion depende del BP): Mediante este indicador se fija si el intervalo de rango de números será de asignación interna o de asignación externa. En intervalos de rango de números de asignación interna se asignarán los números automáticamente por el Sistema SAP. El número asignado automáticamente está entre el 'número de ' y el 'número a'. El último número asignado es grabado en el log como 'número actual'. En la asignación externa deberá indicar el usuario un número que deberá estár entre el 'número de' y el 'número a'.

Asignar rango de números a cuentas de acreedor

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de acreedor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de acreedores -> Asignar rangos de números a grupos de cuentas p.acreedores

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Grupo: Grupos de cuentas de Acreedores

Significado Denominación del Grupos de cuentas de Acreedores.

Rango de números: Rango de numero asignado al Grupos de cuentas de Acreedores.

Configuracion de numeros para Cuentas de Deudor (Cut - Over: XDN1)

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de deudor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de deudores -> Crear rangos de números para ctas.deudores

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Seleccionamos:

N° Rango de números: Acrónimo de 2 dígitos alfanumérico para identificar un rango de numero de Deudor dentro de SAP.

De Numero: límite inferior de un intervalo.

A Numero: límite superior de un intervalo.

Cont. Rango números: En este campo se indica el último número asignado en el intervalo de rango de números de asignación interna. (empeza desde TAL numero)

Ext. (En este caso es externo, porque la numeración depende del BP): Mediante este indicador se fija si el intervalo de rango de números será de asignación interna o de asignación externa. En intervalos de rango de números de asignación interna se asignarán los números automáticamente por el Sistema SAP. El número asignado automáticamente está entre el 'número de ' y el 'número a'. El último número asignado es grabado en el log como 'número actual'. En la asignación externa deberá indicar el usuario un número que deberá estar entre el 'número de' y el 'número a'.

Asignar rango de números a cuentas de Deudor

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Gestión financiera -> Contabilidad de deudores y acreedores -> Cuentas de deudor -> Datos maestros -> Preparar creación de datos maestros de deudores -> Asignar rangos de números a grupos de cuentas para deudores

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Grupo: Grupos de cuentas de Deudores

Significado Denominación del Grupos de cuentas de Deudores

Rango de números: Rango de numero asignado al Grupos de cuentas de Deudores

Integración de numeración de BP con Grupos de cuentas de Acreedores y Deudores

Se deben igualar las numeraciones para que los grupos de cuentas de acreedores y deudores lo heren desde la numeración de la agrupación:

Acreedores

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Sincronización datos maestros -> Integración cliente proveedor -> Parametrizaciones interlocutor comercial -> Opciones para la integración de proveedor -> Especificar función IC en sentido acreedor según IC

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Aquí relacionamos:

Grupo: Grupo de Acreedores

Funcion IC: Funcion de interlocutor comercial en la que se darán de alta.

El interlocutor comercial se crea dentro de la integración de acreedores durante el tratamiento del acreedor con el grupo de cuentas correspondiente en los roles IC a los que se ha asignado este grupo de cuentas.

SPRO è Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Sincronización datos maestros -> Integración cliente proveedor -> Parametrizaciones interlocutor comercial -> Opciones para la integración de proveedor -> Asignación de campos para la integración de proveedor -> Asignar claves -> Especificar asignación de números para dirección IC a acreedor

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Aquí relacionamos:

Agr. (agrupación/clases): Agrupación/clases de Interlocutores comerciales

Descripción breve: Descripción de la clase de interlocutor comercial.

Grupo: Grupo de acreedores

Descripción breve: Descripción del grupo de acreedores

Misma N°: Hace que en la creación de un registro maestro de acreedores se utilice el mismo número que el número del intermediario financiero.

Agr. Var (para pases de SAP ECC a S/4 con CVI): Activar agrupación variable para acreedores. Habilitar gestión flexible de grupos de cuentas y numeración de proveedores. Si se marca esta casilla de selección, el comportamiento del sistema cambia de la forma siguiente:

Habilitar gestión flexible de grupos de cuentas y numeración de proveedores. Si se marca esta casilla de selección, el comportamiento del sistema cambia de la forma siguiente:

  1. No puede seleccionar "mismos números" y "agrupación variable" al mismo tiempo. "Mismos números" precisa la asignación estricta de la agrupación de socios comerciales al grupo de cuentas de proveedor; incluida la validación de rangos de números coincidentes.
  2. Por defecto, el sistema visualiza la asignación de grupos existente como un valor modificable.
  3. La integración de cliente/proveedor (CVI) acepta valores de desviación entrantes para el grupo de cuentas y el número de proveedor. Los valores no se reinician a los valores definidos en el Customizing.

En esta actividad IMG se asigna al grupo de cuentas del registro maestro de deudores el rol IC en el que se debe crear el interlocutor comercial durante el tratamiento de deudor.

Dentro de la integración de deudores, el interlocutor comercial se crea durante el tratamiento del deudor con el grupo de cuentas correspondiente en el rol IC asignado a este grupo de cuentas.

Deudores

SPRO > Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Sincronización datos maestros -> Integración cliente proveedor -> Parametrizaciones interlocutor comercial -> Opciones para la integración de cliente -> Definir función IC para la dirección de cliente a interlocutor comercial

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Aquí relacionamos:

Grupo: Grupo de Deudores

Funcion IC: Funcion de interlocutor comercial en la que se darán de alta.

En esta actividad IMG se asigna al grupo de cuentas del registro maestro de deudores el rol IC en el que se debe crear el interlocutor comercial durante el tratamiento de deudor.

Dentro de la integración de deudores, el interlocutor comercial se crea durante el tratamiento del deudor con el grupo de cuentas correspondiente en el rol IC asignado a este grupo de cuentas.

SPRO è Guía de implementación de Customizing SAP -> Componentes multiaplicaciones -> Sincronización datos maestros -> Integración cliente proveedor -> Parametrizaciones interlocutor comercial -> Opciones para la integración de cliente -> Asignación campos para la integración de cliente -> Asignar claves -> Definir asignac.de números p.dirección de interlocutor comercial a cliente

Ingresamos al punto de customizing:

Aquí relacionamos:

Agr. (agrupación/clases): Agrupación/clases de Interlocutores comerciales

Descripción breve: Descripción de la clase de interlocutor comercial.

Grupo: Grupo de deudores

Descripción breve: Descripción del grupo de deudores

Misma N°: Hace que en la creación de un registro maestro de deudores se utilice el mismo número que el número del intermediario financiero.

Agr. Var (para pases de SAP ECC a S/4 con CVI): Activar agrupación variable para deudores. Habilitar gestión flexible de grupos de cuentas y numeración de deudores. Si se marca esta casilla de selección, el comportamiento del sistema cambia de la forma siguiente:

Habilitar gestión flexible de grupos de cuentas y numeración de clientes. Si se marca esta casilla de selección, el comportamiento del sistema cambia de la forma siguiente:

  1. No puede seleccionar "mismos números" y "agrupación variable" al mismo tiempo. "Mismos números" precisa la asignación estricta de la agrupación de socios comerciales al grupo de cuentas de clientes; incluida la validación de rangos de números coincidentes.
  2. Por defecto, el sistema visualiza la asignación de grupos existente como un valor modificable.
  3. La integración de cliente/proveedor (CVI) acepta valores de desviación entrantes para el grupo de cuentas y el número de proveedor. Los valores no se reinician a los valores definidos en el Customizing.

En esta actividad IMG se asigna al grupo de cuentas del registro maestro de deudores el rol IC en el que se debe crear el interlocutor comercial durante el tratamiento de deudor.

Dentro de la integración de deudores, el interlocutor comercial se crea durante el tratamiento del deudor con el grupo de cuentas correspondiente en el rol IC asignado a este grupo de cuentas.

 

¡Listo! Ya podes dar de alta tu Business Partner en el sistema.

 

03. Temas relevantes para investigar

  • Business Partner y Migraciones: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-members/business-partner-sap-s-4-hana-insights/ba-p/13394671
  • Relaciones en Business Partner: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blogs-by-members/business-partner-creation-with-multiple-contact-persons-relationships-on-s4/ba-p/13474066#comment-591514
  • Implementar CVI: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-members/important-things-to-know-before-starting-cvi/ba-p/13547088

Si esto te sirvió o te interesó por favor no dudes en hacer click en  asi le llega a mas personas.

Muchas gracias por leer.

Saludos.

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 2
entry.content:
Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

In this part, I’ll walk through the SAP Cloud Integration configurations needed to enable the multiple FSM company integration feature. I’ll also highlight some special handling considerations for specific business object types in this setup.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Once the multi-company mapping configuration is completed in the S/4HANA system (as described in Part 1 of this blog series), the next step is to synchronize this mapping data into SAP Cloud Integration as a Value Mapping.

To achieve this:

  1. Configure the Synchronize Multiple Company Mapping Configuration interface according to the standard configuration guide.
  2. Deploy the interface.

When deployed, this process automatically creates a new value mapping artifact:

“Value Mapping for Multiple Company determination in SAP Field Service Management from SAP S/4HANA”

This artifact is stored in the same integration package and is deployed automatically.
It contains all the mapping configuration details in the following format:

The code list values are automatically created by the synchronization interface. For different rule type, the code list values are defined as per below logic:

Category

Value on S4HANA Access Sequence

Value on SAP Field Service Management Account and Company

Standard rule type mapping

<Replication Object>|<Object Attribute type>|<Object Attribute type Value>|<Standard RuleType>|<Rule Value>

Examples:

BP|BPROLE|FLCU00|COMPANYCODE|0001
PR|MATERIALTYPE|ERSA|PLANT|1000
PS|||PLANT|1000

<Account ID>|<Company ID>

Note: if more than one SAP Field Service Management company is mapped for the specific access sequence, it will be populated with comma separation.

Examples:

132132|465465,879497,879846
132132|465465

All Companies configuration

Object Code (such as BP)

ALLCOMPANIES

Custom Rule Type (Set at replication object level)

<Replication Object>
(such as BP)

CUSTOM

Custom Rule Type (Set at replication object attribute level)

<Replication Object>|<Object Attribute type>|<Object Attribute type Value>

Examples:

BP|BPROLE|FLCU00
PR|MATERIALTYPE|ERSA

CUSTOM

Specific Field rule type

<Replication Object>|<Object Attribute type>|<Object Attribute type Value>|<SpecificFieldNumber>|<Specific Field Value>

Examples:

BP|BPROLE|FLCU00|BPFIELD1|IN
PR|MATERIALTYPE|ERSA|PRFIELD1|MG
SO|||PSFIELD1|4987

<Account ID>|<Company ID>

Note: if more than one SAP Field Service Management company is mapped for the specific access sequence, it will be populated with comma separation.

Examples:

132132|465465,879497,879846
132132|465465

 

<SpecificFieldNumber>

Examples:

BPFIELD1
BPFIELD2
PRFIELD1
SOFIELD1

SOAP|<specific field path>,

ODATA|<specific field path> (only for Business Partner object)

 

<ObjectSpecificFieldSize>

Examples:

BPSPECSIZE
PRSPECSIZE

Number of specific fields mapped

In addition to this multiple company value mapping, the synchronization interface will also create a datastore object in SAP Cloud Integration named “FSMCompanyList”, this data store holds the full list of accountId and companyId pairs configured in the multiple company configuration in S4HANA system. This datastore will be utilized in the cases when the business object type is set to replicate all FSM companies using “ALLCOMPANIES” configuration.

After the successful deployment of the multiple company value mapping in the SAP CPI, you need to update the below interfaces to enable multiple company functionality by setting the “EnableMultiCompanyReplication” parameter to true.

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Integration package (Integration of Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Field Service Management)

SAP S/4HANA On premise Integration package (SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management)

Create Business Partner Relationship,

Replicate Business Partner Address,

Replicate Business Partner Contact,

Replicate Business Partner Employee,

Replicate Business Partners,

Replicate Item Group,

Replicate Product Price,

Replicate Product Stock,

Replicate Products,

Replicate Service Order from SAP S4HANA to SAP Field Service Management SOAP,

Assign Service Employee from SAP S4HANA as Warehouse Owner in SAP S4HANA

Create Business Partner Relationship,

Replicate Business Partner Address,

Replicate Business Partner Contact,

Replicate Business Partners,

Replicate Product Price,

Replicate Product Stock,

Replicate Products,

Replicate Service Order from SAP S4HANA Cloud to SAP Field Service Management

 

Enabling this parameter will make the standard interfaces to invoke the Multiple Company integration logic. The interfaces will call the multiple company value mapping to fetch to identify the relevant SAP FSM company id and account id to which the business data to be replicated. This logic is identified in the “Fetch FSM Company” in each interface. Once the FSM company and account id’s are fetched, they are appended to the same incoming message as <FSMAccountID>|<FSMCompanyID> shown below.

Also, the data will be grouped for each FSM account ID and company ID pair for processing into FSM. Each grouped xml message will have the MultiCompanyGroup attribute with corresponding accountId|companyId value. For reference:

If no company Id is found from value mapping for the incoming data, then the account and company IDs are maintained as “NA|NA” and the respective data will be filtered out for replication into FSM. Such data will not be replicated to any SAP FSM company.

Special cases in Multiple FSM company data replication:

When working with multiple company integration between SAP S/4HANA and SAP Field Service Management (FSM), there are a few special cases to be aware of:

  1. No Matching FSM Company ID: If no FSM Company ID is found in the multiple company value mapping, the related data is filtered out and not replicated to any FSM company.
  2. In the integration between SAP S/4HANA Public cloud to SAP FSM
    1. Contact Data Handling:
      • Contact data is stored in the SAP CPI Data Store named BPContacts.
      • A contact is replicated only if it is assigned to a Business Partner.
      • The FSM Company ID is determined from the associated Business Partner using the multiple company mapping rules in the S/4HANA configuration for the Business Partner object.
      • Contacts are loaded into FSM together with their relationship replication.
    2. Data Retention:
      • By default, contact data remains in the CPI Data Store for 30 days.
      • Retention can be extended up to 180 days by adjusting the DS-ExpirationPeriod parameter.
    3. Business Partner Address:
      • FSM Company identification for Business Partner Address data is derived by the parent Business Partner interface, based on the Business Partner object itself.

In the integration between SAP S/4HANA Private cloud and SAP FSM

  1. Employee Data:
    • Employees are replicated to all FSM companies configured in S/4HANA mapping.
    • Assignment to a Service Organization is done later using the Assign Service Employee interface.
  2. Deactivating Unassigned Employees:
    • Employees not linked to any Service Organization can be deactivated using the Delete Business Partner Employee interface, run on an ad-hoc basis.
  3. Contact Data:
    • Contacts are replicated to all FSM companies as inactive.
    • They are activated only when linked to a Business Partner in S/4HANA, together with the relationship replication.
    • Company identification for contacts is based on the associated Business Partner.
  4. Item Group Data:
    • Item groups are replicated to all FSM companies configured in the S/4HANA multiple company mapping.

4. The Service Orders can only to replicated to any one FSM company based on the Sales Area or based on any specific field or using custom logic rule type as defined in the multiple company mapping configuration in S/4HANA. Replicating a single Service Order to multiple FSM companies is not recommended due to conflicts in Service Call ID acknowledgment.

 

This completes the configuration required in the SAP Cloud Integration to enable the multiple company integration functionality. Further, I will share the details on implementing the custom logic functionality to fetch the FSM Company

To be continued…

Click on the below blog link for the third part: Part 3

entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management - Blog Series
entry.content:
Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management - Part 1

The SAP Field Service Management (FSM) landscape is built on two key components: the Account and the Company. While the Account acts as the highest organizational level, a Company represents a specific legal entity, department, or business unit. This structure allows customers to manage multiple companies within a single FSM system to align with their business units. However, this creates a common challenge—replicating data from SAP S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies. Data replication rules often vary depending on factors like Sales Area, Plant, Company Code, or Purchasing Group.

The standard integration content previously had a limitation, allowing data to be sent to only one FSM company at a time from S/4HANA Public or Private Cloud systems. With the 2023 FPS03 release, this limitation has been addressed—enabling standard integration from S/4HANA to multiple FSM Companies.

In this blog series, I’ll explore this new multi-company integration capability for both from S/4HANA public and private cloud system perspective. I’ll also share edge cases where implementing custom logic can help determine the correct FSM Company based on incoming S/4HANA data.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

These multiple company data integration features are available in the latest version of standard integration content:

SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Field Service Management

Integration of Service in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP Field Service Management

 

Supported Data objects for multiple FSM company integration from S/4HANA systems:

Object Name

S/4HANA Public Cloud System

S/4HANA Private Cloud System

Business Partner, Address, Contact and Relationship

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Product, Product Price and Stock

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Material Group, Employee, Service Employee Assignment to warehouse

No

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Service Order

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Yes (via SAP CPI)

Service Contract

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Equipment

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Functional Location

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

Equipment and Functional location Classification

No

Yes (Point to Point integration)

 

Maintain Mapping rules:

As a first step, we need to configure the mapping rules to identify the FSM company id based for the incoming business data. These multiple company mapping rules should be maintained in S/4HANA system.

S/4HANA Public Cloud setup:

In S/4HANA public cloud, open “Manage Your Solution” app, then click on Configure Your Solution. Search for “Integration with SAP Field Service Management” item to configure Multiple Company Replication. If this item is not visible in your solution management, then set the local version to USA.

Here you can define the Rule type for each Business object, there are multiple rule type options available for you to choose like below:

Rule Type Code

Rule Type Field

Description

0

All Companies

Object will be replicated to all defined FSM companies in the configuration

1

Plant

Object will be replicated based on the plant data in the source data

2

Sales Area

Object will be replicated based on the Sales Area data in the source data

3

Company Code

Object will be replicated based on the Company Code data in the source data

4

Purchasing Code

Object will be replicated based on the Purchasing Code data in the source data

5

Purchasing Org

Object will be replicated based on the Purchasing Group data in the source data

6

Specific Field

Object will be replicated based on any field from the source data as defined in the rule mapping. To be used when rule is defined based on non-standard rules like plant, sales area, etc as above.

Configure full list of FSM company Id along with their account id to which the data to be replicated in “Define S/4HANA FSM Company” and Assign FSM Company Details.

 

Now, assign Replication object detail for each FSM Company and relevant rule type filters like Sales Area or Plants or Company Codes, etc.

Recommended mapping configuration for standard rule types is shown as below. But this can be extended for custom rule types as per the business need.

 

Replication object

If you configure rule type as specific field, then the relevant fields must be assign with the path of the field and its value for each company in the mapping configuration. Note: for Business Partner you must configure field path of both SOAP and Odata structure. Refer to the standard Odata and Web service structure of the business object object from SAP Business Accelerator hub.

Note to exclude the root elements from the field path. For reference, follow the below table for specific field path configuration on different object types:

S/4HANA Private Cloud or On premise S/4HANA setup:

In On premise S/4HANA (SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud) system, the multiple company mapping configure remains almost the same but with some additional business objects for replication. Also, in addition available rule types in S/4HANA Public cloud, here you can set up the rule type as Custom Logic. When Custom logic rule type is set for any object, the FSM Company identification happens based on custom code written (requires BAPI) in S/4HANA system.

Execute the below SPRO path for the multiple company configuration.

SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Service -> Integration with Other SAP Solutions -> SAP Field Service Management -> Configure Multiple Company Replication

Below is the required configuration detail for each rule type.

This completes the configuration required in the S/4HANA systems for the multiple company integration. Now, the mapping information should be synchronized to SAP Cloud Integration and few configurations should be enabled in the standard interfaces to make the multiple FSM company integration work.

To be continued…
