entry.title: Seamless Multi-Company Data Replication in SAP Field Service Management – Part 3
entry.content:
Custom Logic in Pre exits and Error Handling in Multiple FSM Company Replication in SAP Cloud Integration

In this blog part, I’ll explain how to use custom exits within the multiple company fetch functionality of standard interfaces to determine the relevant FSM company. I’ll also highlight the enhanced error handling introduced in SAP Cloud Integration as part of the multiple company integration feature.

Blog Series links:

Part 1 - Multiple Company integration overview and preparing S/4HANA systems for Multi-Company Integration

Part 2 - Configurations in CPI and Special handling of Business objects in Multiple Company integration

Part 3 - Achieving Multiple Company integration through custom logic implementation and enhanced error logging

Sometimes, the standard rule types provided by SAP—such as Sales Area, Company Code, etc—may not fit your business requirements for identifying the FSM company. In such cases, you can implement your own custom logic to determine the FSM Company IDs and Account IDs for incoming data. This custom logic can be implemented in multiple ways, depending on your integration scenario and business needs.

.

Custom Logic Using Pre-Exits for Multiple Company in Standard Interfaces:

In the S/4HANA Public Cloud to SAP FSM integration, you can leverage a pre-exit to determine FSM company details dynamically.

To enable this:

  1. In the standard interface where you want to apply custom logic, set the parameter Enable Pre-Exit MultiCompany to true.
  2. Create a Process Direct interface to implement your custom logic for setting FSM Account IDs and Company IDs.
  3. Apply your business rules to assign one or multiple companies as required.

This approach gives you flexibility to map FSM companies based on your specific business criteria before the data is sent to FSM.

 

Sample custom interface with custom logic to identify the FSM company and account id for the business partner object.

In the Groovy step “Set FSM Company details”, I have logic to different FSM account and company based on country code and for the FLCU01 role code. The identified FSM account and company details are appended to the same Business Partner message as in below format.

Similarly, this logic can be extended to any extent as per your requirement.

<FSMMultiCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidA</FSMCompany>
  <FSMCompany>accountid1|companyidB</FSMCompany>
  .
  .
</FSMMultiCompany>

Later in the XSLT step “XSLT Group by FSM Company”, the message is grouped per FSM account and company Id pair using xml attribute “MultiCompanyGroup” as accountid|companyid. This group of data per each FSM account and company pair is required for the further processing of the data into each FSM company by the standard interface. More detail on how to group the message is provided in the following link Multiple Company Pre-Exits.

Final payload which sent back to standard Replicate Business Partner interface is as below. The standard interface will take care of posting the BP data to each FMS company in sequential batches.

In scenario of S/4HANA Private Cloud to SAP FSM integration scenario, you can either use the similar approach of using the pre exits provided for the multiple company fetch in the standard interfaces as shown above OR you can set the rule type as “Custom” in the S/4HANA multiple company configuration for the business object and implement a BADI to identify the FSM company ID in S4HANA.

 

Custom Logic Using Custom rule type in Multiple Company config in S/4HANA:

The Custom Logic rule type is available only for integration between SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and SAP Field Service Management (FSM).

This option allows you to determine the relevant FSM companies using your own code or logic instead of predefined rules. To use it:

  • Create an implementation for the BAdI CRMS4_FSM_RELV_COMP_DETERM.
  • Assign the Custom Logic rule type to the desired Replication Object, Attribute, and Attribute Value in the multiple company configuration.
  • Use the same combination as a filter in your BAdI implementation.
  • If Custom Logic is required for multiple replication objects, create a separate BAdI implementation for each.

Example: To configure custom logic for Sales Customers:

Step 1: Assign Custom Logic Rule Type

  • Replication Object: Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute: BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value: BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

Step 2: Create BAdI Implementation with Filters

  • Replication Object (REPL_OBJECT): Business Partner (BP)
  • Replication Object Attribute (OBJ_ATR): BP Role (02)
  • Replication Object Attribute Value (OBJ_ATR_VAL): BP Customer – Sales (FLCU01)

This approach gives you full flexibility to define custom company determination logic that fits your organization’s business rules, while keeping it aligned with the multiple company integration framework.

 

Enhanced Error Logging in Multi-Company integrations:

In multi-company integration scenarios, SAP Cloud Integration now provides enhanced error logging to simplify troubleshooting and root cause analysis.

When data errors occur during replication to SAP Field Service Management (FSM) companies, the system:

  • Creates attachments in the Message Processing Log (MPL) with detailed error information.
  • Records custom MPL headers indicating the FSM company for which the data failed to load.
  • Generates separate attachments for each FSM company, ensuring issue tracking is company-specific.

If an error is generic (not linked to a specific FSM company), it is still logged in a custom MPL header containing the company and account ID, along with relevant attachments.

Handling Missing Company Assignments

When no FSM company can be determined for an incoming replication object, the object is filtered out and not sent to any FSM company.

  • These filtered object IDs are recorded in a dedicated custom MPL header.
  • All attachment file names are suffixed with the corresponding FSM company ID.
  • If multiple companies are determined for one replication object, separate attachments are created for each.

 

Custom MPL Headers in Multi-Company Error Handling

Custom Header

Value

Purpose

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartner

Business Partner ID

Logs BP ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForBusinessPartnerRelationWithContact

Business Partner ID | Contact ID

Logs BP & Contact IDs filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForProduct

Product ID

Logs Product ID filtered out due to no matching FSM company

FSMCompanyNotFoundForWarehouse

Product ID | Plant | Storage Location

Logs Product, Plant & Storage Location filtered out

FSMCompanyNotFoundForConditionRecord

Condition Record ID

Logs Condition Record ID filtered out

FSMCompanyNotFoundForServiceOrder

Service Order ID

Logs Service Order ID filtered out

BusinessPartnerFailedToLoad

Business Partner ID | FSM Company ID

Logs BP ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ContactFailedToLoad

Contact ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Contact ID & company ID for FSM load errors

BusinessPartnerRelationFailedToLoad

Contact ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Contact ID & company ID for relationship replication errors

ProductFailedtoLoad

Product ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Product ID & company ID for FSM load errors

WarehouseFailedtoLoad

Warehouse External ID

Logs Warehouse external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ItemWarehouseFailedtoLoad

Item Warehouse External ID

Logs Item Warehouse external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

PriceListFailedtoLoad

Price List External ID

Logs Price List external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ItemPriceListFailedtoLoad

Item | Price List ID

Logs Item & Price List external ID & company ID for FSM load errors

ServiceOrderFailedtoLoad

Service Order ID | FSM Company ID

Logs Service Order ID & company ID for FSM load errors

DataFailedtoLoad

FSM Account ID | FSM Company ID

Logs FSM account & company ID for non-FSM specific errors

 

This improved logging framework ensures that every failure—whether company-specific or generic—is captured with context, allowing for faster resolution in complex multi-company setups.

Sample error logging snapshots:

entry.title: SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Why this matters: the upcoming changes turn what looked like a technical switch into a strategic decision that can affect your budget, compliance posture, and HCM roadmap. Activations of Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA directly influence whether you need additional HCM licenses, which capabilities you can keep on-premise versus in Private Cloud, and how quickly you should plan a move to SuccessFactors for certain functions. Getting ahead of this now helps you avoid unplanned costs or audit exposure, prevents disruption to HR processes tied to payroll, time, and regulatory reporting, and gives you time to align contracts, license product codes, and project timelines. The guidance below distills what’s changing and the practical steps to stay compliant while keeping your transformation on track.

Starting with SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Business Function for SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA  will be turned on by default. From this release on, there is no compatibility pack for HCM anymore.  This technical change is not reversible. The licensing requirements are applicable when SAP HCM is utilized beyond the scope of the HR Mini Master, in cases where the customer is conducting HCM processes in the system.

For the technical details, please check the KBA 3443536 - SAP S/4HANA Release 2025 will be delivered with active H4S4_1 Business Function - SAP for Me 

Some functionality is not available in S/4HANA Private Cloud; e.g. SAP Learning Solution is available in S/4HANA on-premise, when moving to Private Cloud, the go-to solution is SuccessFactors Learning.

You can see the details of what features are enabled and what are disabled you can check in the following note 3091160 - SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA – General Approach and Strategy - SAP for Me 

A customer using the HCM compatibility pack today in SAP S/4HANA on-premise can receive a prolongation only if they move to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition, via a lift-and-shift (like-for-like) migration that preserves the current release. If the move includes an upgrade to the 2025 release, the H4S4_1 business function will be active by default, and the HCM compatibility pack will no longer be available, so prolongation does not apply.  With the requested change, they would get the prolongation as well in case they directly move to SuccessFactors, which is our strategic intent.

HCM License Materials and Usage Rights 

 

Customers must also license SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA latest the first day after the expiry of the Compatibility Package.

Please contact your account executive to plan the license conversion as soon as possible. 

I hope you found this blog post helpful. If you did, please give it a "like" or share it. I’d love to hear your thoughts and feedback, so feel free to leave a comment. If you have any questions, just drop them in the Q&A section with the tags SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. We'll try to get back to you as soon as we can.


Thanks,

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG team.

entry.title: Comprehensive Overview “RISE With SAP Methodology Dashboard" within SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Comprehensive Overview “RISE With SAP Methodology Dashboard" within SAP Cloud ALM

The "RISE with SAP" Dashboard with SAP Cloud ALM is a strategic tool designed to support SAP customers on their cloud transformation journey, focusing on maintaining a clean core and ensuring cloud compliance and upgrade readiness.

Purpose and Benefits:

  • Supports transition to SAP S/4HANA Cloud with a focus on minimizing technical debt.
  • Enables faster upgrades and continuous innovation.
  • Improves system performance, reliability, and flexibility.
  • Leverages cloud-based tools like SAP BTP for added functionalities without modifying the core.

Clean Core Approach:

  • Emphasizes reducing customizations and obsolete code.
  • Facilitates easier upgrades, better integration, and system agility.
  • Promotes using cloud tools for extensions rather than core modifications.

Tools and Dashboards:

  • SAP Cloud ALM supports the Clean Core approach by providing dashboards that monitor compliance across different dimensions:
    • System View Dashboard: Provides an overview of system compliance, covering SAP S/4HANA systems in various environments (production, test, development). It tracks data collection status and supports SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.
    • Operation View Dashboard: Offers operational insights, KPIs, and ratings related to system health and compliance on the operational side.
    • Executive Dashboard (Upcoming): Intended for executive-level summaries and strategic decision-making.

Clean Core Dimensions Covered:

  • Extensibility
  • Operations
  • Integrations
  • Data
  • Business Processes

Why SAP Cloud ALM supports the adoption of clean core

Capabilities of” RISE with SAP “ Dashboard

 

Dashboard Structure

Prerequisites:

  • Role assignment by administrators to ensure user access.
  • Active or up-to-date data collection tools for accurate measurement.
  • Support and compatibility with SAP S/4HANA systems.

Data collection for System View Dashboard

  • Data collection occurs weekly.
  • Initial data update may take up to 1.5 weeks after tool activation.
  • Support for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

“RISE WITH SAP” Dashboards 

 

SAP Cloud ALM and RISE with SAP | SAP Help Portal

 

System View Dashboard

  • The System View dashboard gives you an overview of your system's clean core compliance.
  • The System View dashboard supports your SAP S/4HANA systems in production, test, and development.
  • The data for the System View dashboard is collected from your system once a week. After you activate any of the data collection tools, it can take upto 1.5 weeks for the tool status to update and for the initial data to appear in the dashboard. Ensure each tool's status is Active or Up to Date. For more information, see Clean Core Tool Status.
  • Supports SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition systems only

Available dimensions in the Systems View Dashboard

 

  • Software Stack

Software Stack | SAP Help Portal

  • Clean Core Tool Status

Clean Core Tool Status

 

  • Extensibility

Extensibility | SAP Help Portal

This also gives linkage Custom Code Analytics in SAP for me

 

 

 Operations View Dashboard

The Operations View dashboard gives you an overview of your systems' clean core compliance from the operations dimension

operations-view

 

Concept

List of Scores and KPIs

List of KPIs and Metrics

Basically both System View and Operation View Dashboard give ratings/numbers etc , so that customers can take a wise decision how they could plan their cloud journey and make the 5 pillars upgrade ready and cloud complaint and keep the core clean.

entry.title: How to perform a successful Carve-Out in SAP ECC and S/4HANA – Update and New Trends 2025 (Part I)
entry.content:
It has been four years since I published my original five-part series on SAP Carve-Outs - covering basic topics from what a carve out is (Part I), data migration (Part II) and technical orchestration (Part III) to process and analytics considerations (Part IV) and S/4HANA value creation (Part V).

Time for a look back on what has changed since then with new trends for SAP Carve-Outs and Divestiture Projects in business and technology.

The good news is: The core principles and methods outlined in those earlier posts remain as relevant today as they were then.

However, the past four years have brought notable shifts in both business dynamics and technology landscapes, reshaping how carve-out projects must be planned, managed, and executed. In many cases, these changes have introduced greater complexity, requiring organizations to adapt their strategies to ensure success.

From our recent project experience and industry observations, two main drivers stand out:

  1. More complex M&A scenarios – including multi-entity, multi-source, and joint-venture carve-outs, often with heightened compliance and harmonization requirements.
  2. Technology disruption – particularly the accelerated move to the cloud and the looming SAP ECC end-of-maintenance deadlines (2027, or 2030 with costly extended maintenance under SAP RISE).

In this update, I will explore these emerging trends from two perspectives:

Business & M&A Scenario-Driven Trends (Part I):

  • Harmonization of processes and structures during the carve-out to reduce operational complexity post-transition.
  • Multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs that combine data from different systems into a consolidated environment.
  • Enhanced compliance and legal alignment to address stricter regulatory and contractual requirements.
  • Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go-live to keep operations running seamlessly and without any business disruption

Technology-Driven Trends (Part II):

  • Move to cloud – whether via hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud) in private hosting, or through SAP RISE and GROW with SAP offerings.
  • Expanded functional and integration scope – including SAP modules, third-party systems (Salesforce, Ariba, IBP, EDI), and rebuilt analytics landscapes.
  • Combined carve-out and S/4HANA transformation to deliver a modern, value-enhanced system to the buyer.
  • Custom code carve-out and clean-core modernization to simplify future operations and reduce technical debt.

Both parts of this post build on the foundation of the original series, now enriched with current project examples and the latest industry best practices - offering a forward-looking view of what it takes to execute a successful carve-out in 2025 and beyond.

 

Business and M&A Scenario–Driven Trends in Modern SAP Carve-Outs

1. Harmonization of Processes and Structures

In recent years, we have seen a growing emphasis on harmonizing processes and organizational structures during carve-outs – especially to reduce operational complexity after the transition. This is particularly common among private equity buyers, who aim to simplify process variants, adopt industry best practices over heavy customization, and standardize reporting structures across multiple acquisitions. Two main approaches are used:

Option 1: Greenfield Implementation in the Public Cloud

Some buyers opt for a brand-new SAP system - often in an SAP GROW public cloud environment - built entirely on standardized, industry best-practice processes.

  • Advantages: Fast to implement, provides a clean slate, and allows extensions via SAP BTP without burdening the core system.
  • Caveats:
    • Historic data is typically lost, requiring separate archival for audit or business purposes.
    • The “big bang” cutover into entirely new processes can disrupt business operations without strong change management.

This approach is best suited for asset deals or acquisitions of smaller, less complex entities.

Option 2: Selective Data Transition (SDT)

With the right Transformation Software, SDT enables you to migrate only selected data while simultaneously transforming processes, configurations, and structures. For example, in a carve-out involving multiple company codes from a highly integrated environment, intercompany relationships may need to be converted into customer-vendor-structures - requiring both process reconfiguration and master/transactional data transformation.

SDT also allows:

  • Changing charts of accounts, profit/cost centers, plants, and org structures.
  • Transforming open and historical transactional data to match new processes.
  • Maintaining a continuity of historical data in the new environment.

Trade-offs: SDT is more complex, typically requiring 6-12 months for high-complexity projects and demanding greater involvement from both IT and business teams.

We have seen SDT increasingly used in share deals, spin-offs, and large-scale asset divestitures with significant process complexity.

 

2. Multi-Source & Joint-Venture Carve-Outs

Another fast-growing trend involves multi-source and joint-venture carve-outs, where data from multiple ERP systems must be consolidated into one new environment.

Typical scenarios:

  • Multi-source carve-out: Extracting data from several ERP systems (ECC, S/4HANA, or both) within the same organization, often during ongoing SAP S/4HANA transformation projects.
  • Joint-venture setup: Merging data and processes from multiple partners into a shared system.

Challenges include:

  • Harmonizing master data, processes, charts of accounts, and org structures – including historic transactional data.
  • Managing licensing and data visibility between different corporate owners.
  • Separating and rebuilding formerly shared subsystems or third-party integrations.

Given their complexity, these projects nearly always use SDT combined with system merge methodologies, cross-system harmonization, and automation for plant or unit reallocation - while ensuring strict data access controls between Joint-Venture partners.

Additionally, these projects require a significant engagement from SAP specialists to adjust and reshape processes, harmonize data and organizaional structures, properly adjust interfaces to external or cloud-based systems, and enhance data analytics and reporting. Due to the variety of skill sets needed and the urgency in a carve-out project, the setup usually requires engaging with a specialized System Integrator (SI) early in the project planning phase to ensure these topics are successfully covered.

 

3. Enhanced Compliance & Legal Alignment

Stricter regulations and geopolitical constraints now significantly influence carve-out planning and execution.

Examples include:

  • GDPR for companies doing business in EU-countries
  • Industry-specific requirements (e.g., regulated industries like Utilities, Aerospace & Defense).
  • Data sovereignty laws such as China’s DSL, CSL, and PIPL, which can require a separate, localized SAP system, to protect your global business data by keeping it separate.

Implications:

  • Migrate only approved data subsets, particularly personal data.
  • Ensure full audit documentation of extraction, transformation, and loading.
  • Include technical safeguards such as log tracing, reversible deletions, and cutover checks.

Modern SDT Software products - like cbs ET Enterprise Transformer - already offer audit-grade logging for these processes, making compliance easier to prove post-project.

 

Vendor landscape Note:

In the context of the SDT approach, it is worth noting that only four vendors worldwide currently provide both the specialized SDT software and the associated service capabilities needed for complex carve-out scenarios. All are members of the SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement Program and typically collaborate with other system integrators (SI) to cover the full range of services required.

At present, only one of these vendors is able to deliver the complete end-to-end service portfolio independently - an advantage that means fewer communication gaps, with consultants who understand the full scope of services and the role of SDT in the project, rather than working in isolated silos.

Given the sustained market demand for SDT-based initiatives - including both carve-outs and broader SAP S/4HANA transformation projects - delivery capacity can become a bottleneck. To mitigate this risk, organizations should secure delivery slots as early as possible, ideally before the transaction is finalized and the Transition Services Agreement (TSA) is signed, to ensure the resource availability and alignment with agreed project timelines.

 

4. Business Continuity and Operational Excellence during and after go/live

A successful carve-out is not just about getting the technical cutover right - it’s equally about ensuring the carved-out organization can operate smoothly from day one. One of the most significant risks during these projects is operational disruption, which both buyer and seller are highly motivated to avoid before, during, and after the system handover. Maintaining stable business operations has increasingly become therefore a central project goal.

Change Management and Training

Beyond ensuring clean, accurate data in the new system, it is critical to prepare the business workforce for changes to their daily processes and routines. This requires structured change management and targeted training in all areas where processes are being redesigned or where new roles and responsibilities are introduced. This becomes even more important when moving to more standardized, harmonized processes - often with fewer customization and a leaner user interface than in the previous environment.

In such cases, acceptance grows when users understand the why behind the change and are given the tools and guidance to confidently perform their work in the new system. Proper preparation minimizes post–go-live disruption and supports long-term adoption.

Application Management Services (AMS)

In recent years, we have seen a strong trend toward integrating AMS into carve-out project scope from the outset. This is particularly relevant when:

  • The carved-out entity lacks internal SAP expertise after organizational changes or downsizing post-transaction.
  • The seller’s IT services under the TSA come at a premium, and the buyer seeks a faster, more cost-effective transition away from them.
  • The buyer needs a bridging solution until a new internal IT team is in place.

Some AMS providers even offer fractional consulting for small-scale enhancements and process improvements after go-live, adding flexibility during the stabilization phase.

Choosing a provider who delivers AMS as part of a comprehensive business transformation has clear advantages, as they understand carve-out–specific requirements such as altered team responsibilities, new support structures, and heightened service continuity needs.

For smaller and mid-sized organizations, SAP’s M&A Ambassador Program can be a valuable option, particularly for PE-driven carve-outs. It equips these projects with expert partner frameworks to manage both the initial deployment and post-go-live stabilization. Unfortunately, this program does not include any provider with SDT capabilities.

Recommendation: Define AMS scope and contracts early - including infrastructure operations, interface monitoring, patching, SLA targets, and knowledge handover - so that post-go-live operations run as smoothly as the cutover itself.

 

Summary of Part I and Key Takeaways

Over the past years, my team and I have seen, and experienced with our customers, that carve-outs in 2025 are no longer purely IT-driven exercises.They are strategic business transformations requiring early leadership engagement and precise planning.

On the business side, the key success factors are:

  • Early preparation: Business readiness and TSA alignment before signing prevent costly delays.
  • Selective Data Transition (SDT) as a game changer: Enabling selective migration and process harmonization with minimal disruption; early partner selection is crucial given limited global capacity.
  • Integrated service delivery: One provider delivering end-to-end reduces communication gaps and ensures holistic understanding.
  • Business continuity protection: Early investment in process mapping, change management, and training ensures smoother cutovers.
  • Built-in stabilization: Integrating AMS from the onset speeds post–go-live recovery.
  • Organizational change management: Early engagement drives faster adoption and productivity.

For the technical delivery models, toolsets, and SDT-related innovations shaping carve-outs in 2025 and beyond, see Part II of this Update 2025 post.

If you’d like to discuss your own carve-out scenario, feel free to contact me directly. @Lorenz_Praefcke2

entry.title: Standard Integration Packages Plug-and-Play for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 and ESM and Utlities
entry.content:
In today's growing CRM demand faster, more agile implementations with minimal overhead. SAP understands this need and has responded with a new generation of standard integration packages for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2, specially tailored for industries such as Utilities and Enterprise Service Management (ESM). These pre-packaged solutions are designed for plug-and-play integration, eliminating the need for extensive customization and ensuring rapid deployment and value realization.

Why Standard Integration Packages?

Traditionally, integration projects have required significant customization, consulting hours, and effort. This often led to increased costs, longer go-live timelines, and higher maintenance overhead. Standard integration packages reverse this model by offering:

  • Preconfigured scenarios
  • Best practice processes
  • Certified integration content
  • Zero or minimal customization requirements

These benefits help organizations streamline operations, reduce IT complexity, and accelerate time-to-value.

Key Features of the Standard Integration Packages

1. Out-of-the-Box Integration

SAP provides prebuilt connectors and iFlows using SAP Integration Suite (formerly CPI) to integrate SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 with ESM solutions (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Service) and utility backends (e.g., IS-U, S/4HANA Utilities).

2. Industry-Specific Scenarios

These packages cater specifically to industry needs:

  • Utilities: Handle meter-to-cash processes, service request handling, complaint management, and field service coordination.
  • ESM: Manage enterprise-wide service requests, knowledge bases, approvals, and fulfillment workflows.

3. Certified Integration Content

All integration content is:

  • Published in the SAP API Business Hub
  • Regularly updated and maintained by SAP
  • Based on SAP Best Practices and aligned with standard APIs
Standard Integration PackagesDescription of the Package contains
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ Quote integration between SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and SAP CPQ
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP ERPIntegrate sales processes between SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and SAP ERP.
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANAIntegrate sales processes between SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA
SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionIntegrate sales processes between SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Integration for Master Data with SAP S/4HANAIntegrate master data between SAP Sales and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA
SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Integration for Master Data with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionIntegrate master data between SAP Sales and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
Qualtrics Integration with SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2Integration flow for integrating Qualtrics and SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2
SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Integration for Master Data with SAP ERPIntegrate master data between SAP Sales and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP ERP
SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP SuccessFactors Employee CentralEmployee replication from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud Version 2
Sales Cloud Version 2 - Customer Insights Integration with SAP S/4HANAIntegrated transactional data from SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud with Sales Cloud Version 2 - Customer Insights
SAP Service Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP S/4HANAIntegration of service management processes between SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA (Service Management)
SAP Service Cloud V2 for Utilities Contract Account Integration with SAP S/4HANAThis package integrates Utilities Contract Account transactional data between SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA
SAP Service Cloud V2 for Utilities Master Data Integration with SAP S/4HANAThis package integrates Utilities master data between SAP Service Cloud Version 2 and SAP S/4HANA.
SAP Enterprise Service Management Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud

This integration package enables integration between SAP Enterprise Service Management and SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Resources Available to Customers

Customers can access all relevant materials directly via:

  • 📘 SAP API Business Hub: Browse and explore integration packages, iFlows, and APIs
  • 🧰 SAP Best Practices Explorer : Implementation guides, configuration wizards, and sample data
  • 📦 SAP Integration Suite: Central platform to deploy and manage integrations

Conclusion

SAP’s standard integration packages for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 with ESM and Utilities are a game-changer for businesses looking to simplify and speed up their digital transformation. With true plug-and-play functionality, these packages remove traditional barriers to integration and enable organizations to focus on delivering superior customer and service experiences — without the burden of custom development.

entry.title: “Business Excellence with SAP’s New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How”
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

SAP provides pre-delivered content to run your business. A Clean Core approach means keeping Cloud ERP systems up-to-date, free from unnecessary customizations, and aligned with industry best practices. This gives the benefits of driving innovation-readiness, ensuring seamless future upgrades and reducing technical debt.

1.1 Key guiding principles of a Clean Core

There are five essential guiding principles that contribute to an efficient and sustainable Cloud ERP system:

  1. Processes – Streamlining end-to-end (E2E) business workflows for efficiency.
  2. Integration – Ensuring seamless communication between extensions and core enterprise solutions.
  3. Extensibility – Extending standard software functionality to meet unique organizational needs.
  4. Data – Managing configuration, master, and transactional data effectively.
  5. Operations – Managing infrastructure, upgrades, system monitoring, and maintenance.

In this article, we will focus on the “Extensibility” guiding principle.

To support business differentiation while maintaining a Clean Core, organizations can adopt various extensibility models.  A clean core strategy doesn't mean to exclude extensibility entirely, the crucial part is understanding the appropriate way to implement the extensions.  You can create extensions using SAP Build via “Side-by-side” extensibility (loosely coupled) on BTP (including AI-enhanced pro-code and low-code tools) or through “S/4 HANA On-stack” extensibility (tightly coupled).

2. WHY New Clean Core Extensibility Levels:

SAP has refined its clean core model, evolving from the former three-tier structure to a more detailed four-level concept (A, B, C, and D). Instead of a simple “clean vs. not clean” classification. These levels show how closely your custom extensions align with clean core principles.

This evolution provides greater clarity for extension decisions and simplifies qualification criteria, giving organizations a more practical way to balance innovation with long-term sustainability. It’s about making smarter, future-proof extensibility choices while ensuring business differentiation doesn’t come at the cost of technical debt.

Here’s what it means in practice:

  1. Smarter, future-proof choices – Enable meaningful business differentiation without slowing down with legacy overhead.
  2. Clean, scalable extensions – Build on SAP BTP, ABAP Cloud, and SAP Build—all supported by Joule, SAP’s AI copilot.
  3. Progress you can measure – Monitor and track clean core adoption with tools like the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard and ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC). The dashboards will be updated and reflect the new levels.

3. WHAT are the new clean core extensibility Levels:

Before exploring the new clean core extensibility levels are, it is important to understand what an API is—because most of these levels are closely tied to APIs.

  • An API (Application Programming Interface) is essentially a defined set of rules, protocols, and interfaces that allows one software application to communicate with another.
  • In simple terms, an API acts like a bridge. It lets developers access specific functions, data, or services of a system without needing to dive into, or modify, the underlying code.

There are four extensibility levels from the cleanest form of extensions to not clean extensions.

Level A – The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. Represents highest standard in SAP extensibility, offering future-ready solutions with maximum upgrade stability by utilizing released API’s and extension points.

Level B –Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Level C – Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

Level D – Classified as not clean core. This level includes extensions that don’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Below table explains the differences in each level for comparison.

For detailed guidance on frameworks, technologies and development patterns in the context of clean core extensibility, please refer to SAP Note: 3578329.

4. HOW to find SAP extensibility objects classification by levels:

The “SAP Business Accelerator Hub” and “Cloudification Repository (API Viewer)” are the central tools to classify objects by clean core level. It shows which objects are:

  • Released APIs (Level A)
  • Classic APIs (Level B)
  • No APIs (Level D)
  • Internal Objects (Level C – default when not classified as A, B and D)

The SAP API Business Hub is SAP’s central catalog of APIs, integration content, and business services. All the APIs are classified as Level A. Remote APIs are for consumption in BTP and local APIs are for consumption in “On-stack extensibility”.

The Cloudification Repository Viewer is an interactive tool designed to help developers explore API details for “SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public” and “SAP S/4HANA Private Edition” for on-stack extensions.

Links:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
  • SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)

In this article, I will be demonstrating the usage of “S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition”.

4.1 Extension Level A

The cleanest form of custom extensions. These are built either directly on-stack with the ABAP Cloud development model or side-by-side on SAP BTP using SAP Build, whether through ABAP Cloud, CAP, or low-code/no-code tools. You can find the released API’s at SAP Business Accelerator Hub. If you are a developer, you can find the released API’s directly in the IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

 Alternatively, for “SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition" you can follow the below steps.

Detailed Steps:

1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud ERP Private  (Doesn’t include Classic APIs)
2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Released” under State drop down.

4. You have different options to filter results based on “Object type”, “Software Component” and “Application Component”

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “purchase_order”)

4.2 Extension Level B – Classics APIs:

Extensions that follow SAP’s best practices for classic ABAP development and use only officially provided SAP APIs and frameworks. These extensions can be used only if the requirements cannot be fulfilled by set of released APIs (Level A). These include wide range of legacy APIs, user exits, BadIs and established frameworks like SAP GUI and ABAP list viewer grid.

Detailed Steps on finding the Classic API’s:

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar”

3. Choose “Classic API” in the state 

4. You can choose filter criteria as needed

5. You can also search for objects (Example of search results for “sales”)

4.3 Extension Level C – Conditionally Clean

Extensions at Level C involve the use of SAP internal objects that are not classified or intended for customer use. These objects are neither officially released, recommended, nor cloud-ready, and they fall outside SAP’s formal support scope. However, with the introduction of the new changelog for SAP objects (currently in work and will become later available), customers can proactively analyze and plan for potential upgrade impacts when Level C objects are affected by incompatible changes. For this reason, Level C extensions are considered conditionally clean.

  • You can find objects in Level A (Released APIs), Level B (Classical APIs) and Level D (No APIs).

Level C refers to all internal SAP objects that are neither “Released APIs,” “Classical APIs,” nor “APIs” at all. Since they are internal objects, no official list exists.

4.4 Extension Level D – Not Clean Core

Extensions at level D are classified as not clean core. These includes extensions that doesn’t follow SAP’s guidelines, such as system modifications, reliance on non-recommended SAP objects, or unsupported techniques like implicit enhancements.

Detailed Steps on finding objects which are “Not APIs” classified as “No APIs”

  1. Go to S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition (Classic API’s)
  2. Click “Show Filter Bar

3. Choose “No API” in State

4. Results with “No APIs” are displayed

5. Successor information is available for some of the objects.

5. Summary:
With this evolved model, SAP is giving organizations a smarter playbook for extension decisions. By aligning with clean core principles on a clear scale (Levels A, B, C and D), businesses can innovate faster, keep their systems future-ready, and reduce technical debt—while still getting the flexibility they need today.

6. References:
